DOCNAME: CASE OF ERDOĞAN YAĞIZ v. TURKEY
CONCLUSION: Preliminary objection allowed (six month period);Preliminary objection dismissed (non-exhaustion of domestic remedies);Violation of Art. 3;Not necessary to examine Art. 8;Remainder inadmissible;Pecuniary damage and non-pecuniary damage - financial award (global);Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings

TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE Ms GPE lodged a criminal complaint against ORG and ORG , alleging threatening behaviour . She apparently stated that “ a certain PERSON , chief of police ” had protected the CARDINAL men .

CARDINAL . On DATE , at TIME , the applicant , who had been employed as a doctor by the GPE police for DATE , received a telephone call from his supervisor , who asked him to come to the office . As he got out of his car in the car park outside the building , the applicant was stopped by QUANTITY police officers . In front of the members of the public in the courtyard , he was handcuffed and informed that he was under arrest . In the course of his arrest , the applicant told the officers that he was an official police doctor and that there must have been a mistake . He begged them not to handcuff him in front of CARDINAL of people . He was taken into police custody in the organised crime and arms - trafficking branch .

CARDINAL . DATE , without having informed him of the accusations against him , the police took the applicant in handcuffs to his workplace and home , where they carried out searches . It appears that he again asked for the handcuffs to be removed so that his children and neighbours would not see him being restrained . He even suggested that the officers go to his home after sunset so that he would not be exposed to public view . The police officers refused and , moreover , forced him to walk QUANTITY along the road before arriving at his home . During the search he was allegedly insulted in front of his family . The police also seized his official weapon .

CARDINAL . The applicant further maintained that he had signed the records of the searches while in handcuffs , before being escorted back to the police headquarters . He was made to sit on a chair , blindfolded and still in handcuffs , throughout his time in police custody . As the chair was by the entrance to the toilets , he was jostled whenever anyone came past . He heard staff from the headquarters ask why their doctor was in police custody . He refused to drink or eat .
CARDINAL . On DATE a statement was taken from him by the police although he had not been informed of the accusations against him .

CARDINAL . On DATE , DATE and DATE the applicant was examined by a forensic specialist . The subsequent medical reports did not mention any signs of assault . They stated that he was cooperative and lucid , that his faculties had not been impaired and that he had not reported any particular grievances .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was taken to the ORG public prosecutor 's office ; he was later released without being brought before the prosecutor .

CARDINAL . On DATE he was examined by a psychiatrist , who certified him unfit for work for DATE on account of psychiatric trauma . His sick - leave was extended several times on account of acute depression .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a very detailed complaint with ORG concerning his detention in police custody , setting out the circumstances in which he had been arrested , detained and released after DATE without any explanation . He asked the court to inform him why he had been taken into police custody .
CARDINAL . DATE the court replied that he had been questioned in connection with criminal investigation no . DATE because of his relations with suspects .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was informed that he was to be suspended until the end of the criminal investigation on account of his relations with persons who had already been convicted of blackmail , looting and false imprisonment as members of an organised gang .

CARDINAL . On DATE the factory which employed him as a doctor under an individual contract – a post he had found in the private sector – dismissed him , criticising him for his lack of care and attention towards the staff . The letter of dismissal also mentioned that he was undergoing psychiatric treatment .
CARDINAL . In an order of CARDINAL March CARDINAL ORG ruled that the applicant 's official weapon should be returned to him in the absence of any offence or indictment .
CARDINAL . On DATE the public prosecutor 's office discontinued the case against the applicant .

CARDINAL . On DATE , the applicant was reinstated in his post at the police headquarters . However , as he was unable to work in the same department on account of aggravated psychosomatic symptoms , he remained on sick - leave until DATE , when he was admitted to hospital .

CARDINAL . On DATE he was ordered to take early retirement on health grounds , the diagnosis being “ persecution - type hallucination with serious depression ” . He was subsequently admitted to the neuropsychiatry department of ORG on several occasions for psychiatric treatment .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a complaint with the PERSON public prosecutor 's office against CARDINAL police officers , GPE , PERSON , GPE , GPE and GPE , alleging that they had abused their authority and ill - treated him with a view to obtaining a confession . CARDINAL . On DATE ORG refused leave to open a judicial investigation on the ground that no fault was attributable to the police officers .
